question.text: Which of the following is the intermediate compound linking glycolysis to the Krebs' cycle?

solution.text: During glycolysis pyruvic acid is produced from glucose and is oxidatively decarboxylated to form acetyl <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> . The oxidation of pyruvic acid occurs inside matrix of mitochondria and is called as link reaction. It results in production of <math><mn>2</mn></math> molecules of <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> and <math><mn>2</mn></math> molecules of <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> . This acetyl <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is completely oxidised during Krebs' cycle. Thus acetyl <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> acts as the linker of glycolysis and Krebs' cycle.
